* Select "Search" and select "c:\"

* press cancel

This is really a dup of bug #62956.

This is a regression from 3.0
busyCursorWhile() is not showing the blocked dialog until the preference dialog is closed. Tod was this 
change intentional?

This is not a regression. busyCursorWhile never opens a dialog if there is
another modal dialog open so prevent deadlocks.

There was a path where this was possible that was fixed in M6.

The dialog appears in 3.0, in 3.1 it does not. Are you saying the 3.0 behavior was incorrect and the 
current behavior is correct?
In our case the current behavior is undesirable because it does not provide any feedback to the user 
except for busy cursor.

We were never supposed to open a dialog when there is another modal dialog open.
Blocking user input by opening a second dialog is not a solution we can go with.

What is the suggested solution for this? We have a long running process launched from a dialog, that 
should block the UI until it's done and should provide the user feedback while it's running. 
From bug #67894 and bug #67843 we thought that we were doing the correct thing by using 
busyCursorWhile(), but with the behavior change for M6 we're not giving the user any feedback until it's 
too late (ie they've closed the preference dialog)

OK I see more where you are coming from now.

You want to use showInDialog for this - busyCursorWhile is specced to never open
while there is another dialog.

However showInDialog will also have this issue currently because we also block
on the modal shell - it should not block when it is the parent shell that is
modal. I have logged Bug 89900 for this.

If you want to do a stop gap then you could just use a progress dialog but I
will be addressing Bug 89900 in M7.

Switched to using ProgressMonitorDialog.
Tod, thanks for the help
*** Bug 89703 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
